author: By Cihan Tugal
title: Whatever Happens Next, Turkey Is in Trouble
description: Even if Recep Tayyip Erdogan is dethroned, his political project is going nowhere.
content: The Turkish opposition has never been as hopeful as it is today. Despite the many difficulties of the past two decades, never have so many factors lined up against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his Justice and Development Party, or A.K.P.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin and Nicole Sperling
title: Striking Writers Find Their Villain: Netflix
description: Fear of protests prompted the streaming giant to shift an anticipated presentation for advertisers to a virtual event and a top executive to skip an honorary gala.
content: Just over a week after thousands of television and movie writers took to picket lines, Netflix is feeling the heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What Song Represents Your Home?
description: Tell us why it evokes the spirit of the place where you live.
content: Communities around the world have anthems and songs that evoke the emotion of the place and its people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin, Ryan Mac and Tiffany Hsu
title: Elon Musk Says He Has a New C.E.O. for Twitter
description: Mr. Musk is in talks about the role with Linda Yaccarino, chairman of global advertising and partnerships at NBCUniversal, two people with knowledge of the matter said.
content: Elon Musk is in talks to hire Linda Yaccarino, the chair of global advertising and partnerships at NBCUniversal, as chief executive of Twitter, two people with knowledge of the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Trump Revives Election Lies and False Boasts in CNN Town Hall
description: Former President Donald J. Trump misleadingly and wrongly described his own record, the events of Jan. 6, 2021, his handling of classified documents, foreign policy and the economy.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump almost immediately began citing a litany of falsehoods Wednesday night during a town hall-style meeting in New Hampshire broadcast on CNN.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Lyna Bentahar
title: Abortion Access Keeps Winning Elections
description: But advocates can’t agree on a strategy to hold more ballot initiatives.
content: Since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, abortion access has fared very well when it has appeared on the ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: W.H.O. Ends Mpox Global Emergency
description: The virus was contained in most countries with a combination of vaccination and behavioral change.
content: The World Health Organization announced on Thursday that mpox — previously known as monkeypox — no longer constituted a public health emergency, almost exactly a year after the virus emerged as a threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Suggests He Knowingly Took Documents From White House
description: The former president, in his appearance on CNN, misstated the law governing presidential records, saying he was allowed to take the material now at the heart of a Justice Department investigation.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump admitted more directly than before on Wednesday that he knowingly removed government records from the White House and claimed that he was allowed to take anything he wanted with him as personal records, appearing to misstate the law and undercut some assertions by his own lawyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Christopher Maag
title: New York City Starts Busing Migrants North. Counties Are Fighting It.
description: Dozens of migrants moved into a hotel in the town of Newburgh on Thursday, even as officials there sought an injunction to prevent that from happening.
content: NEWBURGH, N.Y. — After days of angry standoffs over the possibility of New York City busing migrants to nearby suburban counties, two busloads of migrants arrived Thursday at a hotel in Newburgh, in Orange County, about 60 miles north of Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: When Did ‘Wholesome’ Become a Gen Z Compliment?
description: For a young generation, the word has come to embody everything pure and true.
content: When Celeste Scott sees “things that are unscathed by the bad things in the world,” she says she can’t help but blurt out: “That’s so wholesome.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Anne Mancuso
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s homes are a three-bedroom in Bedminster, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Chappaqua, N.Y.
content: A three-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath, 4,726-square-foot country estate built in 1973 with formal living and dining rooms, newly remodeled kitchen and bathrooms, three fireplaces, a family room and a library, on six acres with two double garages and a rentable one-bedroom cottage. Gerry-Jo Cranmer, Turpin Realtors, 908-234-9100, turpinrealtors.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Fool’s Paradise’ Review: No Talent? No Problem!
description: A hapless man who barely speaks becomes a movie star in Charlie Day’s scattershot Hollywood satire.
content: Charlie Day casts himself as a passive, nearly silent actor, Latte Pronto, in his feature directing debut, “Fool’s Paradise.” There’s something grudgingly admirable about the voluble star essentially spending an entire film doing reactions. But it’s a disastrous move in a Hollywood satire that already needs to be more than a grab bag of jokes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: Yunchan Lim, Teenage Piano Star, Arrives in New York
description: The 19-year-old musician made his New York Philharmonic debut with a powerful yet poetic performance of Rachmaninoff’s Third Concerto.
content: “He plays like a dream,” we say about musicians we like, meaning simply that they’re very good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall, Shashank Bengali, Lara Jakes and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Zelensky, Citing Equipment Gaps, Says It’s Too Soon for Counteroffensive
description: Ukraine’s president played down the chance of an imminent military move, but the claim was greeted with some skepticism.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — President Volodymyr Zelensky said Thursday that Ukraine needed more time to begin a counteroffensive against Russia because it does not yet have enough military equipment from its Western backers, though Ukrainian officials had repeatedly described the assault as imminent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Baseball’s Most Unusual Hitter Finds His Own Way
description: Luis Arraez of the Miami Marlins is hitting nearly .400 despite having one of the game’s softest swings. He could become the third player with a batting title in each league.
content: Last year, Luis Arraez spoiled Aaron Judge’s shot at a triple crown by beating him out for the American League’s batting title. This year, after being traded from the Minnesota Twins to the Miami Marlins, Arraez could join another Yankee, DJ LeMahieu, in one of the rarest distinctions in baseball: winning a batting crown in both leagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Red-Carpet Companion
description: Sheldon Polonsky gets physical.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: Onstage in Brooklyn, ‘Monsoon Wedding’ Tries to Capture the Film’s Spirit
description: Mira Nair’s long-gestating musical, based on her 2001 hit indie film, arrives at St. Ann’s Warehouse.
content: The director Mira Nair was standing inside St. Ann’s Warehouse last week, pointing at a marigold-covered archway that was being assembled near the entrance. Conscious of the wedding photo shoots that often happen just outside the space, she was talking about the musical adaptation of her 2001 film, “Monsoon Wedding,” at the theater, which, situated along the Dumbo waterfront and a stone’s throw from where the East and Hudson Rivers merge. “That’s what our show is about,” she said. “Confluence.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘BlackBerry’ Review: Big Dreams, Little Keyboards
description: The struggle to sell a revolutionary gizmo fractures a friendship in this lively, bittersweet comedy.
content: In Matt Johnson’s “BlackBerry” — a wonky workplace comedy that slowly shades into tragedy — the emergence of the smartphone isn’t greeted with fizzing fireworks and popping champagne corks. Instead, Johnson and his co-writer, Matthew Miller (adapting Jacquie McNish and Sean Silcoff’s 2015 book “Losing the Signal: The Untold Story Behind the Extraordinary Rise and Spectacular Fall of BlackBerry”), have fashioned a tale of scrabbling toward success that tempers its humor with an oddly moving wistfulness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Friends Once ‘Escaped’ Her Cooking. Now, She’s One of the World’s Best Chefs.
description: Ana Ros broke through the boys’ club of fine dining, earning Hisa Franko in Slovenia two Michelin stars and a spot on the list of the world’s best restaurants.
content: “Transforming Spaces” is a series about women driving change in sometimes unexpected places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: On the Border, on the Cusp of Change
description: Miriam Jordan, The Times’s national immigration correspondent, is covering a major shift in border policy this week.
content: As an international correspondent for Reuters and The Wall Street Journal, Miriam Jordan reported from India, Hong Kong, Israel, Mexico and Brazil. When she returned to the United States in 2004, she found a way to keep her reporting global: by covering immigration. Her experience and language skills (besides English, Ms. Jordan speaks Spanish, Portuguese, French and Hebrew) were well-suited to the beat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: How Bailey Zimmerman Charmed Nashville
description: In short order, the 23-year-old singer-songwriter has the top song at country radio, a slot on the biggest tour of the summer and a rousing new album. He’s trying not to fumble.
content: NASHVILLE — The spoils of fame are coming fast for the emerging country star Bailey Zimmerman. The Texas singer-songwriter Cody Johnson gave him a standing offer to come ride horses at his ranch. The Nickelback frontman Chad Kroeger flew him on a private plane to his home in Canada to spend some time writing songs. The guitar whiz Gary Clark Jr. and the singing ex-rapper Jelly Roll partied with him backstage at the CMT Awards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Stephen Castle
title: Britain says it is donating long-range ‘Storm Shadow’ missiles to Ukraine.
description: The missiles, which are launched from the air, are the latest in a pipeline of military aid delivered to the country by Britain, the United States and other NATO allies.
content: Britain is donating long-range Storm Shadow missiles to Ukraine to help it reclaim territory lost to Russia since the start of its invasion, Britain’s defense secretary, Ben Wallace, told Parliament on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Bad Cinderella’ to Close on Broadway, Ending Lloyd Webber’s Streak
description: When it concludes on June 4, an unbroken string of Andrew Lloyd Webber shows since 1979 will come to an end. His latest opened only in March.
content: “Bad Cinderella,” a revisionist riff on the classic fairy tale, will close on June 4, bringing to an end, at least for the time being, composer Andrew Lloyd Webber’s 43-year-long streak of shows on Broadway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: House Approves Stringent G.O.P. Border Bill, Attacking Biden on Immigration
description: The legislation, which seeks to revive, codify and stiffen a series of border policies pursued by the Trump administration, was timed to be considered on the eve of an expected border surge.
content: House Republicans pushed through a sweeping border security bill on Thursday that would crack down on unlawful immigration, blowing past solid Democratic opposition and narrowly avoiding an embarrassing mutiny within their own ranks on one of their signature midterm campaign promises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeneen Interlandi
title: America Is Forgetting the Lessons of the Covid Health Emergency
description: Despite many failures, the nation still got several things right.
content: This is part of a series on preparing for future outbreaks. Sign up for our newsletter, the Next Pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Monica’ Review: Mother and Daughter, Both Alike in Dignity
description: Trace Lysette and Patricia Clarkson star in this subtle chamber drama.
content: The characters in the family drama “Monica” are not a talkative bunch, at least not with each other. Monica (Trace Lysette) is a transgender woman who has learned, at great cost, what it means to be alone. She was expelled from her home by her mother, Eugenia (Patricia Clarkson), at a young age. Now she works as a massage therapist by day, and collects extra tips by doing video sex work. She endures with panache the indignities of other people’s interest, brushing off harassers with confident ease. Yet her most intimate moments consist of one-sided conversations. Monica makes calls to her absentee lover. She begs for a response, but her pleas go to voice mail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Ukraine’s advance near Bakhmut.
content: Ukrainian troops have broken through Russian positions outside the embattled eastern city of Bakhmut and forced Russian units back from a key position near a canal, commanders on both sides said, the first gains since March for Kyiv’s forces in the fight for the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Police in Europe Ask for Help in Identifying 22 Murdered Women
description: Their bodies were found over the years in Belgium, Germany and the Netherlands. A new campaign aims to find out who they were.
content: LONDON — On Christmas Day 1990, hikers found the body of a young woman hidden under a rug and wrapped in blankets in a park in the Netherlands, not far from the Belgian border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Mad May: 10 Art Fairs in NYC
description: This week and next, expect a deluge of art, with TEFAF, Frieze and satellite exhibitions spread around the city, from TriBeCa to Chelsea to Manhattanville.
content: If the last two years represented a slow return and then full-on bounce back to prepandemic arts programming, the array of art fairs this May embodies something of a spring frenzy. Here’s a guide to our favorites, by neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saul Austerlitz
title: When ‘Homicide’ Hit Its Stride
description: The influential crime drama debuted 30 years ago. Here, the creators and stars reflect on its legacy and on an early episode that served notice that it was a different sort of cop show.
content: For television historians amateur and professional, the easiest place to begin the story of the contemporary Golden Age of Television is on Jan. 10, 1999, when Tony Soprano first paid a toll on the New Jersey Turnpike. But perhaps we might be better served to rewind the clock approximately six years, to Jan. 31, 1993, the night of Super Bowl XXVII. The Dallas Cowboys demolished the Buffalo Bills, 52-17, and the broadcast was followed by the premiere of a new NBC drama, set in Baltimore, studying the work of the city’s homicide detectives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Before Smartphones and the National Weather Service, There Was Grandma’s Knee
description: Humans have long depended on weather forecasts for survival. While observations of the sky can make for reliable predictions, experts say, those of animal activity can lead weather-watchers astray.
content: I thought my grandmother was psychic. One day in the mid ’90s, in Richmond, Va., where I grew up, the temperature had climbed above 100 degrees as it often did during the height of summer. Everything seemed to be melting under the oppressive heat that day. My grandmother looked down and began to vigorously massage her knees, like a soothsayer rubs a crystal ball. Staring at me, she said, “It’s gon’ storm.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalia Richardson
title: Here’s What to Know About ‘Queen Charlotte: A Bridgerton Story’
description: The show’s creator, Shonda Rhimes, and a few historians spoke about the facts, fantasy and controversy surrounding Netflix’s new prequel series to “Bridgerton.”
content: With her withering glares and colossal wigs, Queen Charlotte has become a treasured character in the first two seasons of “Bridgerton,” the steamy hit Netflix series set in an alternate, racially diverse version of Regency Era Britain. As played by Golda Rosheuvel, she is a hard-line matriarch with an ear for gossip and an eye for beauty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: E.P.A. Proposes First Limits on Climate Pollution From Existing Power Plants
description: It’s the last in a string of major regulations proposed by the Biden administration to sharply cut the greenhouse gases produced by the United States.
content: The Biden administration on Thursday announced the first regulations to limit greenhouse pollution from existing power plants, capping an unparalleled string of climate policies that, taken together, could substantially reduce the nation’s contribution to global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Trainer of Onetime Derby Favorite Is Disciplined in Doping Case
description: Forte, the Kentucky Derby favorite until he was scratched with an injury, failed a drug test last September. His trainer, Todd Pletcher, received a 10-day suspension and a $1,000 fine.
content: New York regulators on Thursday suspended the Hall of Fame trainer Todd Pletcher for 10 days, fined him $1,000 and disqualified his colt Forte — the favorite in last week’s Kentucky Derby until he was scratched because of an injury — as the winner of a stakes race last September in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 11, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, May 11, 2023.
content: An article on Wednesday about a new recommendation from health experts urging women to start regular mammograms at age 40 misidentified the age at which breast cancer rates decrease. More cases are diagnosed after age 55; the risk does not decline at that age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘L’immensità’ Review: Roman Holiday
description: Loosely based on the transgender director Emanuele Crialese’s transition, this Italian period drama is a sun-dappled nostalgia trip bristling with Oedipal tension.
content: Penélope Cruz is a vision of tragic beauty when she first appears in the Italian period drama “L’immensità.” The camera captures her in adoring close-up as it grazes over her eyes, traced with black eyeliner and wet with tears. Her character, Clara, is an ordinary upper middle-class mother of three, but in the mind of her eldest, Andrew (Luana Giuliani), she’s a goddess akin to the nation’s great stars, like Monica Vitti or Sophia Loren.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our TV critic recommends the most recent season of “Documentary Now!” and the American version of “The Great British Baking Show.” (It’s actually good!)
content: ‘Documentary Now!’When to watch: Now, on Netflix or AMC+.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Lisa Friedman
title: A Swaggering Clean-Energy Pioneer, With $400 Billion to Hand Out
description: Jigar Shah runs a federal program that suddenly has a gusher of money to lend before the next election.
content: The hotel ballroom was packed before breakfast as Jigar Shah took the stage at the oil and gas industry’s annual conference in Houston this spring. The host joked he was confident a huge crowd would come out for Mr. Shah, even at 7:30 a.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval, Eileen Sullivan and Miriam Jordan
title: Some Texas border cities are already under a state of emergency.
description: El Paso area leaders are trying to prevent an immigration crisis like the one they saw late last year when a surge of migrants overloaded area shelters
content: The day before Title 42 was scheduled to end, hundreds of migrants gathered on the banks of the Rio Grande near Brownsville, Texas. Some of them cut a hole through a fence and made it to onto U.S. soil before uniformed agents resealed the barricade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lora Kelley
title: Peloton Shares Slide After It Recalls Two Million Exercise Bikes
description: The company is offering to replace seat posts on the bikes after receiving 35 reports of the equipment breaking.
content: Peloton, the maker of home exercise equipment, said on Thursday that it was recalling more than two million exercise bikes, an announcement that sent its stock lower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Unfinished Business’ Review: Skimming the Surface of Women’s Basketball
description: Unfortunately, this documentary about the W.N.B.A. and the New York Liberty hits the rim and then bounces out — it’s only close to good.
content: This documentary about professional women’s basketball keeps toggling between two subjects so big, each could easily fill an entire series: the W.N.B.A. and one of its founding teams, the New York Liberty. The title refers both to the league’s constant battle for recognition since its creation in 1996 and the Liberty’s fruitless (so far) quest for a title. But “unfinished business” also describes this scattershot film, which is directed by Alison Klayman (“The Brink,” “Jagged”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie Kozolchyk
title: Putting the ‘Springs’ Back in Palm Springs
description: A new spa at the California resort city’s original — and only — hot spring, adds to a growing number of retreats in the Coachella Valley where you can soak the stress away.
content: Palm Springs conjures many images in the popular imagination: California oasis, Old Hollywood hide-out, golf and tennis hot spot, midcentury modern pilgrimage site. But long before Richard Neutra’s airy, glassy Kaufmann House or John Lautner’s concrete-domed Elrod House, there was Welwood Murray’s rickety wooden bathhouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark
title: U.S. Focuses on Invigorating ‘Chiplets’ to Stay Cutting-Edge in Tech
description: Chiplets, a way to design chips for higher performance, has become a key prong of U.S. industrial policy. But pushing for more of this activity domestically is challenging.
content: For more than 50 years, designers of computer chips mainly used one tactic to boost performance: They shrank electronic components to pack more power onto each piece of silicon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Stepping Into Big Shoes, Anne Hillerman Walked in a New Direction
description: Tony Hillerman’s daughter had her own dreams for one of the stars of his novels. Now she carries on the family tradition, with a few twists.
content: Anne Hillerman never planned to become the steward of her father’s characters. But a decade after Tony Hillerman, the prolific mystery writer and chronicler of the Southwest, died in 2008, his daughter came around to the idea of immortalizing three of his recurring protagonists — Bernadette Manuelito, Jim Chee and Joe Leaphorn, who work for the Navajo Tribal Police — in novels of her own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: George Santos: An Accused Con Man Who Happened to Trade in Politics
description: In federal prosecutors’ eyes, Mr. Santos is a grifter with a taste for fame and designer goods, willing to lie and defraud donors to get ahead.
content: By all appearances, the summer of 2020 was a very good time for George Santos. He was pulling in a six-figure salary from a Florida-based investment firm, and he had won the Republican Party’s support as a first-time candidate contesting a Long Island House seat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: Before Taylor Swift or David Bowie, There Was Sarah Bernhardt
description: A centenary exhibition in Paris honors the French actress who invented the concept of the global star.
content: In the 19th and early 20th century, everyone worshiped at the altar of Sarah Bernhardt. She was a stage actress at a time when the theater was the equivalent of a stadium, a global celebrity who ushered in the very concept.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: The Great C.S.A. Dilemma
description: You’re swimming in beets and chard. Now what?
content: For those equally frustrated by supermarket markups and interested in supporting local farmers, a C.S.A., or community-supported agriculture program, has a lot to offer. Chief among the benefits is that a mystery box of fruits and vegetables makes every week (or every other week or every month, depending on your program’s model) feel like your birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: Five Takeaways From Trump’s Unruly CNN Town Hall
description: Behaving as the Republicans’ de facto nominee, Donald Trump dug in on his 2020 lies and dodged on abortion. The G.O.P. audience cheered, but so did Democrats seeking 2024 fodder.
content: Donald Trump is still Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A ‘Rude and Inaccurate’ Trump at the CNN Town Hall
description: Readers discuss whether the network should have provided the forum to the ex-president. Also: George Santos; “Anxious Nation”; informal connections.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Okoyomon and Anne Boyer
title: Poem: The World Is Breaking in Flowers the Breath of Things
description: Darkness has a speed, and motion — hovering, being, flowing, breathing — unifies this poem and its world.
content: Much like Precious Okoyomon’s visual works — living installations that invent new lyric ecosystems — this poem starts with love, then offers a landscape. The body’s scale aligns with the cosmic one. History appears, too, with its wars and cities, its incendiary nature, its souvenir of ash. Feeling has substance. Darkness has a speed, and motion — hovering, being, flowing, breathing — unifies this poem and its world. Selected by Anne Boyer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Upholds California Law on Humane Treatment of Pigs
description: The court ruled that the measure did not violate constitutional limits on state laws that affect conduct beyond the state’s borders.
content: The Supreme Court on Thursday upheld a California law that sought to address cruelty to animals, saying the state could require pork sold there but produced elsewhere to come from breeding pigs housed in spaces that allow them to move around freely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raúl Vilchis and Julie Bosman
title: Lejos de la frontera, los autobuses con migrantes han empezado a llegar
description: Manuel Castro, comisionado de migración de la ciudad de Nueva York, dijo que hasta 1000 migrantes podrían llegar cada día en las próximas semanas.
content: Más de una semana antes de la fecha prevista del fin del Título 42, un autobús llegó a la terminal de autobuses Port Authority en el centro de Manhattan a las 7 a. m. en punto. A bordo iban 41 migrantes recién llegados.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: F.B.I. Violations of Rules for Searching Surveillance Data Drop, Audit Finds
description: The bureau is trying to show improvement as a provision granting it expanded surveillance powers is set to expire unless Congress acts.
content: Recent changes by the Federal Bureau of Investigation appear to have significantly improved compliance with rules limiting when agents may access communications intercepted under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, according to data from the bureau’s auditing office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Is Everyone Playing Padel Without Us?
description: Americans, bewitched by pickleball, are late to a global sports craze.
content: SANTIAGO, Chile — There are only a handful of places to play pickleball here in Chile’s capital. Next month, there will be one fewer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raúl Vilchis and Julie Bosman
title: More migrant buses have already begun arriving in cities far from the border.
description: Manuel Castro, New York City’s immigration commissioner, said that up to 1,000 migrants could arrive daily in the coming weeks.
content: More than a week before the anticipated lifting of Title 42, a bus pulled into the Port Authority bus terminal in midtown Manhattan at 7 a.m. sharp, carrying 41 new migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Stephanie Lai
title: Trump’s Second-Term Goal: Shattering the Norms He Didn’t Already Break
description: The former president made it clearer than ever this week that on issues including Ukraine, the economy and the rule of law, his return to office would lead to a sharp departure from core American values.
content: In little over an hour, Donald J. Trump suggested the United States should default on its debts for the first time in history, injected doubt over the country’s commitment to defending Ukraine from Russia’s invasion, dangled pardons for most of the Capitol rioters convicted of crimes, and refused to say he would abide by the results of the next presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Las reglas de inmigración vuelven a lo habitual: el Título 8
description: El vencimiento del Título 42 significa que los agentes fronterizos federales volverán el viernes a las reglas habituales para hacer cumplir la ley de inmigración, conocidas como Título 8.
content: Con el fin del Título 42, la política de la era covid que permitía la rápida expulsión de los migrantes que llegaban a Estados Unidos, los agentes fronterizos federales deben regresar el viernes a las reglas previas a la pandemia para hacer cumplir la ley de inmigración, conocidas como Título 8.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: How Many Square Feet Does $1,500 a Month Get You?
description: Here’s where renters get the most and least space for the money in large U.S. cities.
content: Right now, a household earning the national median income of $70,784 a year can afford about $1,775 in monthly rent without becoming “rent burdened” (meaning that 30 percent of income is needed to cover rent). But of course, not every U.S. rental market is the same. A new study by RentCafe gives renters some guidance on which of the country’s 100 largest metro areas offer the most space for the money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
description: This week’s properties are on the Upper West Side, in the Financial district and in Crown Heights.
content: A one-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath, 995-square-foot apartment with white oak chevron floors, an open living and dining area, a bedroom with a walk-in closet and en suite bath with a double vanity and heated floors, ample closet space, a washer/dryer, a smart thermostat and central air-conditioning, on the third floor of a 16-story 1927 doorman building with a resident’s manager, porter, handyman, lounge, garden, gym, children’s playroom, game room, pet spa, remote work spaces, laundry and bike rooms, additional storage and a courtyard. Louise Phillips Forbes, Brown Harris Stevens, 917-846-8640; bhsusa.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Appeals Court Overturns Fraud and Conspiracy Convictions in Varsity Blues Scandal
description: A three-judge panel found that a lower court made crucial missteps in the trial of Gamal Abdelaziz and John Wilson, the first parents to take their chances in front of a jury.
content: In a stunning reversal, a federal appeals court overturned the fraud and conspiracy convictions on Wednesday of two parents found guilty of participating in a far-reaching bribery scheme, known as Operation Varsity Blues, which ensnared dozens of wealthy parents who falsified their children’s credentials to gain admission to prestigious universities across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: How FTX Missed a Potentially Lucrative Opportunity
description: A decision to offload warrants to buy an obscure cryptocurrency token as part of the exchange’s bankruptcy proceedings may have been costly.
content: Working through the bankruptcy of FTX, Sam Bankman-Fried’s collapsed crypto exchange, is proving more complicated all the time. The latest evidence: a potentially lucrative missed opportunity that’s come to light after FTX offloaded warrants to buy an obscure crypto token.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Newell-Hanson and Jared Soares
title: A Fantastical Art Gallery Masquerading as a Suburban Garage
description: In Arlington, Va., Margaret Bakke has made the exhibition space in her driveway a celebration of creativity.
content: ON A QUIET residential street in Arlington, Va., one garage is not like the others. Clad in white corrugated steel, the structure is tall and thin with a sharply peaked roof, suggesting a giant pencil poking up through the earth. And while its neighbors might house minivans and power tools, on a gray December afternoon the door to this one, which is not really a garage at all, opens to reveal a cross-shaped plywood table set, as if for a meal, with brightly colored wares. At the center of the spread are a pair of ornately dimpled pastel-glazed earthenware vases by the French ceramist Saraï Delfendahl, each the size and silhouette of a baby elephant’s foot. A chubby-armed sky blue ceramic chandelier by the New York-based artist Braxton Congrove hangs from the ceiling. The 12 unique place settings feature, among other items, an orange tumbler with three spiky legs by the New York-based artist and tableware designer Grace Whiteside and a clay oyster plate inlaid with shells by the ceramist Michele Mirisola of Brooklyn. Surprising even the gallerist Margaret Bakke, 38, the curator of this exhibition, some of the artists had taken her concept of a dinner party-themed show several steps further by contributing unsolicited additions, including two punch bowls and a poodle-topped butter dish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: TEFAF New York: A Worldly Fair Overflows With Art and Design
description: Nearly 100 exhibitors fill the Park Avenue Armory in Manhattan with furniture, jewelry, art and antiquities spanning millenniums.
content: If you put the Metropolitan Museum of Art in a blender, you might end up with something like TEFAF New York. One of two annual fairs staged by the European Fine Art Foundation (the other is in Maastricht), it fills the historic Park Avenue Armory in Manhattan to its rafters this week with modern and contemporary art and design objects, even spilling into the hallways and up to the second floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Jacklyn Zeman, Nurse Bobbie on ‘General Hospital,’ Dies at 70
description: , She played the same role on the popular soap opera for nearly half a century and was nominated for four Daytime Emmy Awards.
content: Jacklyn Zeman, an Emmy-nominated actress who for nearly a half-century played the role of Bobbie Spencer, a nurse on the long-running soap opera “General Hospital,” died on Tuesday in Thousand Oaks, Calif. She was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Vulnerable Republicans Caught in the Middle in Debt Limit Fight
description: House G.O.P. lawmakers in competitive seats who could be crucial to averting a catastrophic default are being fawned over by Democrats one minute and pummeled the next.
content: Representative Mike Lawler, the first-term Republican from a Hudson Valley suburb who is widely considered one of the most politically endangered members of his party, began the week facing brutal attacks from a major House Democratic political group that falsely accused him of trying to force cuts to Medicare and Social Security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Supreme Court Throws Out Fraud Convictions in Albany Scandals
description: In a pair of unanimous rulings, the court sided with Joseph Percoco, a former aide to Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York, and Louis Ciminelli, a contractor in Buffalo.
content: The Supreme Court on Thursday threw out two fraud convictions during Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s administration in New York, dealing prosecutors the latest in a series of setbacks in their efforts to pursue federal charges of public corruption in state government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Bank of England Raises Interest Rates to Highest Level in 15 Years
description: The central bank lifted its benchmark rate a quarter point, to 4.5 percent, as part of its aggressive policy to tame inflation, but forecast that Britain was likely to avoid a recession.
content: The Bank of England raised interest rates on Thursday, its 12th consecutive increase, as Britain’s inflation rate remained stubbornly in the double digits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: What We Learned About Trump’s Policies in Contentious Town Hall
description: Former President Donald J. Trump staked out positions on several major issues, including separating migrant children from their parents and pardoning Jan. 6 rioters.
content: Among the barrage of falsehoods and bluster, former President Donald J. Trump laid markers down on several major and divisive issues at the CNN town-hall meeting on Wednesday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Panorama of New York Enters the Digital Age
description: The Queens Museum’s huge model of the city was built for the 1964 World’s Fair. Now an interactive tool has been added.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at a new way to view a model of New York City that’s so big it takes up the floor of a former roller-staking rink. We’ll also look at Mayor Eric Adams’s latest comments on the death of Jordan Neely in the subway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Yellen Calls Invoking 14th Amendment to Raise Debt Limit ‘Legally Questionable’
description: The Treasury secretary warned that a default would lead to a “very substantial downturn.”
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen on Thursday downplayed the possibility that President Biden could essentially ignore the debt limit by invoking the 14th Amendment, calling the idea “legally questionable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Eileen Sullivan
title: Estas son las nuevas medidas del gobierno de Biden para afrontar la llegada de migrantes
description: Las nuevas y estrictas reglas de asilo y las vías alternativas para solicitarlo están diseñadas para disuadir a grandes grupos de migrantes de viajar a la frontera.
content: El levantamiento del Título 42 elimina una herramienta clave que el gobierno federal ha utilizado durante más de tres años para reducir la cantidad de migrantes que cruzan a Estados Unidos. En total, aproximadamente la mitad de todos los migrantes encontrados en la frontera desde marzo de 2020 han sido expulsados en cuestión de minutos bajo esta medida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Still: A Michael J. Fox Movie’ Review: Hiding in Plain Sight
description: The “Back to the Future” star time-travels through his career in this documentary, charting his experiences learning to live with Parkinson’s disease.
content: With apologies to Dr. Emmett Brown, you don’t need a flux capacitor to build a time machine. All you need to do is make a film. “Still: A Michael J. Fox Movie,” a new biographical documentary from Davis Guggenheim (“An Inconvenient Truth”), zips through the “Back to the Future” actor’s career with humor and style; it gives the impression that its subject is willing to answer any question. Fox appears, head-on, in contemporary interviews with an off-camera Guggenheim. None of the charisma and charm that made him a star have diminished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Bell
title: A Family Drama Unfolds as Ecological Disasters Mount
description: “Blue Skies,” by T.C. Boyle, considers life in a coastal America made increasingly untenable by climate change.
content: “Blue Skies,” T.C. Boyle’s 19th novel, opens with Cat, a would-be social media influencer living on the imperiled Florida coast, buying a pet Burmese python as a piece of “living jewelry” she hopes will boost her Instagram account. Having been denied her other hoped-for adornments (a baby or a dog or even a cat), she makes her reptilian purchase from the owner of a store regrettably named Herps, who promises, “Nothing’ll make you happier than having a snake in your life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: This Man Is Not Meghan Markle
description: Online jokesters claimed that Karl Jenkins was the Duchess of Sussex in disguise at the coronation. He sets the record straight.
content: Karl Jenkins, a 79-year-old Welsh composer, stressed in a phone interview on Thursday that he is not Meghan Markle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: F.D.A. Eases Ban on Blood Donations From Gay and Bisexual Men
description: But men who had multiple sex partners or were taking PrEP medications in the last three months would still be barred from donating blood.
content: The Food and Drug Administration announced on Thursday that it had formally ended the agency’s wide-ranging prohibition on blood donations from gay and bisexual men, a longstanding policy that had been denounced as discriminatory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada, Lydia Polgreen and Phoebe Lett
title: ‘Matter of Opinion’: What if We Just Paid Clarence Thomas $1 Million?
description: What to think about the scandal-prone justice and the Supreme Court? Our hosts talk it through.
content: On the inaugural episode of “Matter of Opinion,” a new podcast from New York Times Opinion, our hosts Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen discuss the recent revelations about Clarence Thomas, their impact on the Supreme Court and how, or whether, to fix this increasingly unpopular institution. Plus: hot and cold. (What is that? You’ll have to listen to find out.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: This Designer Wants You to Look ‘Powerful’ on Your Wedding Day
description: Sally LaPointe’s first bridal collection bucks the constraints of tradition while celebrating brides who embrace their confidence and the risqué.
content: On April 4, 2022, Sally LaPointe, designer, co-founder and creative director of her namesake company, LaPointe, a ready-to-wear, monochromatic color-driven luxury fashion brand, took on an additional role — host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: N.F.L. Reveals Broadcast Ambitions With 2023 Schedule
description: Aaron Rodgers and the Jets will play the Miami Dolphins in a Black Friday game that will air on Amazon, as pro football continues its expansion of the regular-season lineup.
content: The first N.F.L. game held on the Friday after Thanksgiving. The option for TV networks to swap games. A franchise playing two international games in a single season. Teams having to begrudgingly play two Thursday Night Football games in one season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Jerome Robbins Delivers the Hit of City Ballet’s Season
description: After 15 years, New York City Ballet revives “Brandenburg,” the choreographer’s final ballet, with a sparkling new cast.
content: No choreographer wants to make a dance when he can’t really dance. But Jerome Robbins found himself in that position in 1995 when he began creating “Brandenburg,” set to a complete concerto by Bach and movements from three others. At least he had the music on his side. Robbins once said of the Bach, “It doesn’t seem like something by an old man,” and added: “He’s taking strange journeys while searching out all the things he wants to find out.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: As Covid Emergency Ends, Surveillance Shifts to the Sewers
description: With other virus tracking efforts winding down, wastewater data is likely to become increasingly important in the months ahead, scientists say.
content: When the Covid-19 public health emergency expires in the United States on Thursday, the coronavirus will not disappear. But many of the data streams that have helped Americans monitor the virus will go dark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Michael Crowley
title: Sudan’s Clashing Forces Agree to Allow Aid In, but Not to a Truce, U.S. Says
description: Officials hope the agreement will allow the delivery of lifesaving aid and ease conditions for the millions of Sudanese suffering after nearly four weeks of fighting between rival generals.
content: The warring parties in Sudan could not agree to a cease-fire, but signed a commitment to allow deliveries of humanitarian aid and to restore some services for residents battered by nearly four weeks of intense fighting, two senior U.S. administration officials said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Judge in Virginia Strikes Down Federal Limit on Age of Handgun Buyers
description: The ruling in Richmond is one of the first successful challenges to gun control laws under the Supreme Court’s landmark 2022 Bruen decision.
content: A judge in Virginia has struck down federal laws blocking handgun sales to buyers over 18 and under 21, in a ruling that might augur the rollback of regulation prompted by the Supreme Court’s sweeping expansion of gun rights last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Simonson
title: Inside the Quest for Totally Transparent Cocktail Ice
description: After 14 years of research, the writer Camper English is putting everything he’s learned into his new guide for at-home bartenders, “The Ice Book.”
content: Camper English’s obsession with ice began with its opposite: boiling water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Run-Up' Team
title: The Anti-Trump Republicans (and the Specter of 2016)
description: Larry Hogan and Asa Hutchinson, both Republican former governors, on how — and why — they came to different decisions about running against Trump.
content: The 2016 Republican primary field was crowded. At one point, 17 people were vying for the nomination. It was a pileup that many saw as leading directly to the ascent of Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Why Are All Those People Outside H&M, Again?
description: How consumers became obsessed with fashion collaborations, courtesy of the Swedish mall staple.
content: The year is 2015. The Supreme Court has ruled in favor of same-sex marriage. Negotiations are about to begin on the Paris Climate Accords. Mainstream pop culture is essentially “Hamilton,” “Hotline Bling” and true crime docuseries. And Olivier Rousteing is at the H&M store on the Champs-Élysées, where he is starting to feel the pressure of the pandemonium outside. A policeman, he recalled, told him it was unsafe and he should leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Alex Marshall
title: Undaunted by Air Raids, a Ukrainian Duo Gets Ready for Eurovision
description: With a song inspired by the bravery of Ukrainian soldiers, the pop group Tvorchi sees the beloved, often campy global song competition as a serious opportunity to represent their country.
content: Whenever their rehearsals for the Eurovision Song Contest were interrupted by air raid sirens, the Ukrainian pop duo Tvorchi would race to the safety of underground bunkers, sometimes wearing their matching stage outfits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha Schwendener
title: The Independent, More Inclusive Than Ever
description: Important lessons absorbed from cultural upheavals have translated into a more thoughtful fair around issues of representation.
content: If you were holding your breath for another art fair filled to the steel-girder ceilings with contemporary painting, you can let go. The Independent, the local-brand fair that features art ranging from emerging to the radical old-guard, is not it. The current edition at Spring Studios in TriBeCa, which opens to the public Friday, includes 69 exhibitors from 11 countries, lots of photography and ephemera, idiosyncratic installations, and career resets — and yes, a healthy dose of painting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Solomon
title: Van Gogh and the Consolation of Trees
description: A revelatory show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art reunites 24 paintings of cypresses and unchains them from their somber associations.
content: It might seem logical that Vincent van Gogh, the most famous depressive in all of art, adopted the Mediterranean cypress tree as a motif. The tall, tapered, cone-shaped evergreen has always carried associations of mourning and death. It stands sentinel in Christian, Jewish and Muslim cemeteries across southern Europe and the Near East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Families of Those Lost to Covid Wrestle With Mixed Emotions as Emergency Ends
description: More than 1.1 million Americans have died of Covid. An official end to the health emergency has landed in complicated ways for those affected most acutely.
content: Shannon Cummings, 53, has tried to push forward after her husband, Larry, a college professor, died of Covid-19 in March 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: Reptilian Accessories That Make Coldblooded Look Cool
description: Scale up bags and boots with stylish skins, from embossed python to real croc.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Skapinker
title: Why You’re Probably Hearing Less About Corporate Climate Initiatives
description: Amid accusations of “greenwashing” and “woke capitalism,” some business advisers say staying quiet might be the best option.
content: In the last week of April, around three in 10 voting shareholders at Goldman Sachs, Wells Fargo and Bank of America backed resolutions demanding that the banks explain how they were dealing with climate change. In the same week, Morningstar, the data provider, said that the first quarter of 2023 had been the weakest for the launch of new “sustainable” funds in three years, partly because of investor sensitivity to accusations of “greenwashing,” or the misrepresentation of climate initiatives. This followed a congressional measure to prevent retirement plan managers from even considering social and climate issues in their investments (which President Biden vetoed).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: K-Pop Stars BTS Will Release a Book Telling Their Own Story in July
description: The announcement by their U.S. publisher, Flatiron Books, came after days of frantic speculation by their fervent fans.
content: The K-pop juggernaut BTS will release an oral history of the group in South Korea and the United States on July 9, its U.S. publisher, Flatiron Books, said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘The Starling Girl’ Review: As the Spirit Moves
description: Eliza Scanlen plays a pious teenager who begins an affair with her youth pastor in this tender coming-of-age drama.
content: In the fundamentalist Christian enclave where “The Starling Girl” takes place, Jem Starling (Eliza Scanlen) is a sensitive 17-year-old who nonetheless cannot escape the idea that she is prone to selfishness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse, Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport
title: Meeting Between Biden and Republicans Delayed as Sides Pursue Debt Limit Deal
description: The decision to delay Friday’s expected meeting to next week was cast as a positive development, one that could allow officials to find agreement before the United States defaults on its debt.
content: President Biden and top congressional leaders on Thursday postponed a second meeting on the debt limit crisis to give staff members more time to explore a budget deal before the two sides convened again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What Students Are Saying About A.I.-Generated Music
description: When a fake Drake and The Weeknd track went viral, we asked young people: Will A.I. replace pop stars? Here’s what they think.
content: One of our most popular recent writing prompts was inspired by an A.I.-generated track with fake Drake and the Weeknd vocals that went viral on social media last month, racking up millions of plays. The song was eventually removed from streaming platforms, but not before sending a scare throughout the music industry about the future of artificial intelligence in music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Five Photography Assignments That Invite You to Look Closely at the World
description: Students, try one of these exercises inspired by the visual series The Take. What can you learn about the world by looking at it through a particular lens?
content: How often do you look — really look — at the world around you? Below, we offer five photography assignments that challenge students to do just that, all inspired by The New York Times visual series The Take.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Offutt
title: A Murder Mystery Complicated by War and Its Aftermath
description: Kevin Powers brings together a military thriller and police procedural in his new novel, “A Line in the Sand.”
content: First and foremost, “A Line in the Sand” is a stunning novel. Kevin Powers provides what any discerning reader desires the most — complex and flawed characters, precise use of language, succinct description and believable dialogue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
title: CNN Chairman Defends Decision to Host Trump Town Hall
description: “People woke up, and they know what the stakes are in this election in a way that they didn’t the day before,” Chris Licht said in a morning call at the network.
content: The chairman of CNN, Chris Licht, issued a robust defense on Thursday of his decision to broadcast a live town hall with former President Donald J. Trump, an unruly and at times bewildering event that has prompted criticism inside and outside of the network.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: What is Title 8?
description: The end of Title 42 means federal border agents will return on Friday to the usual rules for enforcing immigration law, known as Title 8.
content: With the end of Title 42, the Covid-era policy that allowed for the swift expulsion of migrants arriving in the United States, federal border agents were set to return on Friday to the prepandemic rules for enforcing immigration law, known as Title 8.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Mary Wilson, Eric Krupke, Diana Nguyen, Liz O. Baylen, Rachel Quester, Michael Benoist, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Even More Trouble for George Santos
description: The Republican congressman was charged with 13 counts of felony, including stealing public funds.
content: Last year, Times reporting revealed the many lies that the freshman Republican congressman George Santos had told about his life and career. Now he is facing legal consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: U.S. News Releases Its Latest, Disputed Rankings of Law and Medical Schools
description: After protests and a boycott, the publication has altered its methodology. But the changes are unlikely to placate critics.
content: U.S. News & World Report finally released its annual rankings of top law and medical schools on Thursday, after boycotts by those institutions, disputes over methodology, and a delay of weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Kaitlan Collins, in a White Suit, Takes on Trump
description: Amid a night of verbal parrying, the CNN host made another statement.
content: She knew what she was in for: the talking over her, the bluster, the alternate version of history, the controversy. She was as prepared as possible. And she was dressed for the arena.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: splay
description: This word has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word splay has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 3 in “From Lil Buck, History and a Chance to Flash Some Brilliance” by Brian Seibert:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Eileen Sullivan
title: Here’s how the Biden administration has prepared for an expected migrant influx.
description: Tough new asylum rules and alternative pathways to apply from home are designed to discourage large numbers of migrants from traveling to the border.
content: The lifting of Title 42 removes a key tool that the federal government has used for more than three years to reduce the number of migrants crossing into the United States. All told, about half of all migrants encountered at the border since March 2020 have been expelled under the measure in a matter of minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: It’s Tennis vs. Pickleball vs. Padel. Or Is It?
description: Private clubs and public facilities are striving to be more things to more people as they try to defuse the tension between tennis and fast-growing racket sports like pickleball.
content: SAN DIEGO — The official name of the facility is the Barnes Tennis Center, but once through the front doors, it quickly becomes apparent that it might want to consider expanding its branding.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: The sometimes blurry line between creator and creation is at the center of three of our recommended titles this week: Colin Winnette’s twisty novel “Users,” about a virtual reality developer brought low by public outrage; Benjamin Balint’s “Bruno Schulz: An Artist, a Murder, and the Hijacking of History,” about the legacy of the great Polish writer and artist who was killed by a Gestapo officer in 1942; and Claire Dederer’s “Monsters: A Fan’s Dilemma,” about how to reconcile our love of great art with our distaste, even revulsion, for some of the people who make it. (“Good Art, Bad People,” as the Book Review’s cover summarized the issue — bearing in mind that the definitions of both are more slippery than we might care to admit.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Jack Ewing
title: How Russia’s Rich Get Their Luxuries Now
description: More than a year into Vladimir Putin’s invasion, the web of global trade has adjusted to Western sanctions, with a network of middlemen sending cars, electronics and more to Russia.
content: On a dusty roadside on the outskirts of Dubai, Sohrab Fani is profiting from the West’s response to the war in Ukraine: his shop installs seat heaters into cars being re-exported to Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Hurubie Meko and Andy Newman
title: Daniel Penny Will Be Charged in Subway Chokehold Killing of Jordan Neely
description: Mr. Penny choked Mr. Neely for several minutes on the floor of an F train. He is expected to surrender on Friday and be charged with manslaughter.
content: Daniel Penny, the 24-year-old Marine veteran who choked and killed a homeless man on the subway last week, will face a charge of second-degree manslaughter and is expected to appear in Manhattan Criminal Court on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘It Ain’t Over’ Review: When Yogi Berra Saw a Strike, He Hit It
description: The baseball player, known for his quirky malapropisms, was perpetually underestimated. But a new documentary proves he was a phenomenal talent.
content: The main brief of “It Ain’t Over,” a lively, engaging and moving documentary is more or less stated upfront by a friendly but mildly indignant Lindsay Berra, the granddaughter of its subject, the baseball player Yogi Berra.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Belkin
title: Heather Armstrong Was the Original Influencer
description: With her blog, Dooce, she ushered in an age of confessional writing online by women, inspiring millions of readers and creators to come.
content: Though I have been given credit, I did not call Heather Armstrong “Queen of the Mommy Bloggers” in my 2011 article for The New York Times Magazine. The headline writer gave her that title, which she wore until Wednesday morning, when nearly every obituary seemed to invoke it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Kemal Dervis, Who Eased Turkey’s Economic Crisis, Dies at 74
description: Changes he spearheaded in 2001 helped avert disaster. He later led the United Nations Development Program.
content: Kemal Dervis, an economist who was instrumental in leading his native Turkey out of an economic crisis early in this century, and who later became the first person to lead the United Nations Development Program from a country that had received developmental aid from the program, died on Sunday in Bethesda, Md. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che and John Liu
title: ‘De-Americanize’: How China Is Remaking Its Chip Business
description: Seven months after Washington unveiled tough curbs, Chinese companies are doubling down on homegrown supply chains and drawing billions in cash from Beijing and investors.
content: Last October, construction plans for a hulking semiconductor factory owned by a major state-backed company in central China fell into disarray. The Biden administration had escalated the trade war over technology, severing China’s access to the Western tools and skilled workers it needed to build the most advanced semiconductors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Liu and Paul Mozur
title: Taiwan Is Running Low on a Strategic Asset: Engineers
description: Taiwan’s world-dominating microchip sector was built by TSMC’s skilled employees. But a demographic crisis, demanding work culture and flagging interest threaten its lead.
content: Engineers like Royale Lee, 31, are one reason Taiwan is the world’s biggest contract producer of the microchips that power almost all electronics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Suspect in Natalee Holloway’s Aruba Disappearance to Be Extradited to U.S.
description: Joran van der Sloot is a suspect in the 2005 disappearance of the American teenager. He has been serving a 28-year prison sentence in Peru for a separate murder conviction.
content: A man connected to the 2005 disappearance in Aruba of Natalee Holloway, an American teenager, will be temporarily extradited to the United States from Peru to face charges that he extorted her mother, the Peruvian authorities said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel and Gaza Trade Fire Amid Cease-Fire Talks
description: After the militant organization Islamic Jihad fired hundreds of projectiles at Israel, Israeli forces stepped up its campaign of killing top commanders of the group in airstrikes.
content: The Israeli military and Islamic Jihad, a Palestinian militant group in Gaza, traded fire Thursday amid mounting tensions in the region as Israel stepped up its campaign of targeted assassinations of Islamic Jihad commanders, killing two more to take the toll to five in three days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: The U.S. ambassador to South Africa accused the country of providing weapons to Russia.
description: The American ambassador to South Africa told reporters that Washington is confident a Russian ship picked up a load of weapons and ammunition near Cape Town in December.

With a cast this beloved, who cares what they’re reading? This sequel opens with a formal quote from “The Alchemist” and, when pressed, mutters about how its author Paulo Coelho embraces fate.
